content.title: Aspergillosis
content.summary: Spectrum of pulmonary diseases caused by Aspergillus species, ranging from allergic (ABPA) to chronic (aspergilloma, CPA) to invasive forms depending on host immune status
key_points: Aspergillus fumigatus is most common pathogen
Disease spectrum depends on host immune status
ABPA in asthmatics/CF - allergic response, IgE elevation, fleeting infiltrates
Aspergilloma - fungus ball in preexisting cavity (TB, sarcoid)
Diagnosis: Galactomannan antigen, beta-D-glucan, culture, BAL, biopsy
Voriconazole is first-line for invasive; itraconazole for ABPA

statement.text: Aspergillosis encompasses a spectrum of diseases caused by Aspergillus species (most commonly A. fumigatus). Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) occurs in asthmatics and CF patients as a hypersensitivity reaction. Aspergilloma is a fungus ball colonizing a preexisting lung cavity. Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) causes progressive lung destruction in immunocompetent hosts with structural lung disease. Invasive aspergillosis is a life-threatening infection in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with prolonged neutropenia. Voriconazole is first-line therapy for invasive disease.
statement.formal: Aspergillosis spectrum = ABPA (allergic) | Aspergilloma (colonization) | CPA (chronic) | Invasive (immunocompromised)

explanation.intuition: Aspergillus spores are everywhere in the environment - we inhale them daily without harm. What happens when spores reach the lungs depends on immune status. In allergic individuals, spores trigger an exaggerated immune response (ABPA). In those with lung cavities from old disease, spores can grow into a fungus ball without invading tissue. In the severely immunocompromised, Aspergillus invades blood vessels and tissue, causing life-threatening infection.
explanation.key_insight: The clinical manifestation is determined by the immune response: hypersensitivity (ABPA in allergic patients), saprophytic (aspergilloma in cavities), chronic destructive (CPA in structural disease), or invasive angioinvasive (neutropenic, transplant). Treatment differs markedly - steroids for ABPA, antifungals for invasive, surgery for aspergilloma with hemoptysis.
explanation.technical_details: Galactomannan is a cell wall component detectable in serum and BAL in invasive disease (sensitivity ~70% serum, ~85% BAL). Halo sign (ground-glass halo around nodule from hemorrhage) on CT is early finding of invasive aspergillosis. Voriconazole achieves better outcomes than amphotericin B for invasive disease. Isavuconazole is an alternative with fewer drug interactions.

definitions_glossary.aspergillus: Genus of ubiquitous molds; A. fumigatus most common human pathogen
definitions_glossary.abpa: Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis; hypersensitivity reaction in asthma/CF patients
definitions_glossary.aspergilloma: Fungus ball colonizing preexisting pulmonary cavity; 'mobile mass' on imaging
definitions_glossary.invasive_aspergillosis: Tissue-invasive infection in immunocompromised; angioinvasive with high mortality
definitions_glossary.chronic_pulmonary_aspergillosis: Slowly progressive aspergillus infection in structural lung disease
definitions_glossary.galactomannan: Aspergillus cell wall polysaccharide; biomarker for invasive disease
definitions_glossary.beta_d_glucan: Pan-fungal cell wall marker; elevated in aspergillosis and other fungal infections
definitions_glossary.halo_sign: CT finding of ground-glass halo around nodule from hemorrhagic infarction
definitions_glossary.air_crescent_sign: CT finding as necrotic lesion cavitates during neutrophil recovery
definitions_glossary.angioinvasion: Fungal invasion of blood vessels causing thrombosis and infarction
definitions_glossary.voriconazole: Triazole antifungal; first-line for invasive aspergillosis
definitions_glossary.itraconazole: Triazole antifungal; used for ABPA and chronic aspergillosis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Aspergillus spores (conidia) are inhaled constantly. Normally, mucociliary clearance and alveolar macrophages eliminate them. In ABPA, spores trigger IgE-mediated and cell-mediated hypersensitivity in genetically susceptible hosts. In cavitary disease, spores germinate and form a fungus ball without tissue invasion. In neutropenia or severe immunosuppression, hyphae invade tissues and blood vessels, causing infarction and dissemination.

disease_spectrum.abpa: Th2 hypersensitivity; IgE elevation, eosinophilia, bronchiectasis
disease_spectrum.aspergilloma: Saprophytic colonization of preexisting cavity (TB, sarcoid, cavity)
disease_spectrum.cpa: Slowly progressive destruction in structural lung disease; cavitation over months-years
disease_spectrum.invasive: Angioinvasive infection in neutropenia, transplant, high-dose steroids; 30-50% mortality

abpa.clinical: Asthma or CF with worsening symptoms, central bronchiectasis
abpa.labs: Total IgE >1000, Aspergillus-specific IgE/IgG, eosinophilia, positive skin test
abpa.imaging: Fleeting infiltrates, mucoid impaction, central bronchiectasis

invasive.at_risk: Neutropenia >10 days, transplant, high-dose steroids, GVHD
invasive.imaging: Nodules, halo sign, air-crescent sign, cavitation
invasive.micro: Culture, histopathology showing septate branching hyphae

abpa.first_line: Systemic corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg) for acute exacerbations
abpa.steroid_sparing: Itraconazole to reduce fungal burden and steroid dose

aspergilloma.surgery: Resection for recurrent hemoptysis, localized disease

invasive.first_line: Voriconazole 6mg/kg q12h x2 doses then 4mg/kg q12h
invasive.alternatives: Isavuconazole, liposomal amphotericin B, combination therapy
invasive.duration: Minimum 6-12 weeks; depends on response and immune recovery
invasive.source_control: Surgical resection if localized and surgically accessible

definition.@value: Spectrum of pulmonary diseases caused by Aspergillus species, ranging from allergic to invasive forms depending on host immune status

skos.scopeNote: Covers ABPA, aspergilloma, CPA, and invasive aspergillosis; includes diagnosis and treatment
skos.example: A neutropenic leukemia patient develops fever, cough, and chest CT showing nodule with halo sign; galactomannan positive; started on voriconazole for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis

learning_objectives: Classify aspergillosis by host immune status and clinical presentation
Diagnose invasive aspergillosis using clinical, imaging, and biomarker criteria
Select appropriate antifungal therapy for each aspergillosis type
Recognize ABPA in asthma and cystic fibrosis patients
clinical_pearls: Halo sign on CT in febrile neutropenic patient = think invasive aspergillosis
ABPA = asthma + central bronchiectasis + high IgE + positive Aspergillus IgE/IgG
Voriconazole is first-line for invasive; check trough levels (target 1-5 Î¼g/mL)
Galactomannan most useful in neutropenic patients; less sensitive in non-neutropenic
Aspergilloma in old TB cavity - 'ping pong ball' that moves with position
Air crescent sign = good sign - means neutrophils recovering and forming cavity around necrotic lesion

board_yield.usmle_step2: High - diagnosis and treatment by type

common_misconceptions: All aspergillosis needs antifungals (false - ABPA treated with steroids primarily)
Positive sputum culture = disease (false - may be colonization; need clinical context)
Amphotericin B is first-line for invasive (false - voriconazole preferred based on trials)
